12.76.text: When I was six years old,

16.32.text:
My first grade teacher
had this brilliant idea.

19.80.text:
She wanted us to experience
receiving gifts

23.16.text:
but also learning the virtue
of complimenting each other.

27.64.text:
So she had all of us
come to the front of the classroom,

30.56.text:
and she bought all of us gifts
and stacked them in the corner.

34.80.text:
"Why don't we just stand here
and compliment each other?

37.48.text: If you hear your name called,

39.08.text: go and pick up your gift and sit down."

48.40.text: Well, there were 40 of us to start with,

50.48.text:
and every time I heard
someone's name called,

52.96.text: I would give out the heartiest cheer.

55.28.text: And then there were 20 people left,

62.96.text: And I was one of them.

67.56.text: Well, at that moment, I was crying.

70.60.text: And the teacher was freaking out.

72.64.text:
She was like, "Hey, would anyone
say anything nice about these people?"

77.56.text:
"No one? OK, why don't you
go get your gift and sit down.

81.84.text:
someone might say
something nice about you."

86.52.text: Well, as I'm describing this you,

88.16.text:
you probably know
I remember this really well.

92.80.text: But I don't know who felt worse that day.

94.92.text: Was it me or the teacher?

97.12.text:
She must have realized
that she turned a team-building event

100.28.text:
into a public roast
for three six-year-olds.

105.08.text:
You know, when you see
people get roasted on TV,

108.68.text: There was nothing funny about that day.

111.32.text: So that was one version of me,

114.36.text:
and I would die to avoid
being in that situation again --

117.88.text: to get rejected in public again.

124.40.text: Bill Gates came to my hometown --

130.64.text: I fell in love with that guy.

132.96.text:
I thought, wow,
I know what I want to do now.

135.88.text: That night I wrote a letter to my family

140.36.text:
I will build the biggest
company in the world,

143.00.text: and that company will buy Microsoft."

146.88.text:
I totally embraced this idea
of conquering the world --

151.16.text:
And I didn't make this up,
I did write that letter.

157.36.text: You don't have to read this through --

161.00.text:
This is also bad handwriting,
but I did highlight some key words.

171.28.text: that was another version of me:

173.32.text: one who will conquer the world.

177.36.text:
I was presented with the opportunity
to come to the United States.

182.92.text:
because that was
where Bill Gates lived, right?

186.40.text:
I thought that was the start
of my entrepreneur journey.

193.32.text: Nope, I didn't build that company.

197.28.text:
I was actually a marketing manager
for a Fortune 500 company.

201.28.text: And I felt I was stuck;

206.32.text:
Where is that 14-year-old
who wrote that letter?

209.48.text: It's not because he didn't try.

211.48.text: It's because every time I had a new idea,

214.56.text: every time I wanted to try something new,

217.80.text: I wanted to make a proposal,

219.56.text:
I wanted to speak up
in front of people in a group --

223.12.text: I felt there was this constant battle

227.76.text: One wanted to conquer the world --

233.96.text: And every time that six-year-old won.

237.76.text:
And this fear even persisted
after I started my own company.

241.76.text:
I mean, I started
my own company when I was 30 --

244.92.text: if you want to be Bill Gates,

246.36.text:
you've got to start
sooner or later, right?

251.64.text:
I was presented
with an investment opportunity,

254.56.text: and then I was turned down.

258.80.text:
It hurt me so bad
that I wanted to quit right there.

264.52.text:
hey, would Bill Gates quit
after a simple investment rejection?

268.92.text:
Would any successful
entrepreneur quit like that?

273.20.text: And this is where it clicked for me.

275.20.text: OK, I can build a better company.

277.04.text:
I can build a better
team or better product,

280.84.text: I've got to be a better leader.

282.72.text: I've got to be a better person.

284.72.text:
I cannot let that six-year-old
keep dictating my life anymore.

288.12.text: I have to put him back in his place.

291.00.text:
So this is where I went online
and looked for help.

295.88.text:
I searched, "How do I overcome
the fear of rejection?"

298.96.text:
I came up with a bunch
of psychology articles

301.84.text:
about where the fear
and pain are coming from.

304.72.text:
Then I came up with a bunch
of "rah-rah" inspirational articles

308.04.text:
about "Don't take it personally,
just overcome it."

314.48.text: But why was I still so scared?

316.64.text: Then I found this website by luck.

323.64.text:
"Rejection Therapy" was this game
invented by this Canadian entrepreneur.

329.32.text:
And basically the idea is for 30 days
you go out and look for rejection,

334.44.text: and every day get rejected at something,

336.72.text:
and then by the end,
you desensitize yourself from the pain.

344.48.text:
I said, "You know what?
I'm going to do this.

346.64.text:
And I'll feel myself
getting rejected 100 days."

349.68.text: And I came up with my own rejection ideas,

352.12.text: and I made a video blog out of it.

355.60.text: And so here's what I did.

357.56.text: This is what the blog looked like.

367.72.text:
So this is where I went
to where I was working.

372.24.text:
and I saw this big guy
sitting behind a desk.

374.48.text: He looked like a security guard.

379.56.text:
and that was the longest
walk of my life --

381.92.text:
hair on the back
of my neck standing up,

384.08.text: I was sweating and my heart was pounding.

386.56.text: And I got there and said,

387.80.text:
"Hey, sir, can I borrow
100 dollars from you?"

391.84.text: And he looked up, he's like, "No."

396.20.text: And I just said, "No? I'm sorry."

398.52.text:
Then I turned around,
and I just ran.

406.20.text:
so that night I was watching
myself getting rejected,

409.36.text: I just saw how scared I was.

411.48.text:
I looked like this kid
in "The Sixth Sense."

417.04.text: But then I saw this guy.

418.60.text: You know, he wasn't that menacing.

420.52.text: He was a chubby, loveable guy,

426.40.text: In fact, he invited me to explain myself.

428.84.text: And I could've said many things.

430.44.text:
I could've explained,
I could've negotiated.

432.76.text: I didn't do any of that.

437.16.text:
I felt, wow, this is like
a microcosm of my life.

440.92.text: Every time I felt the slightest rejection,

443.48.text: I would just run as fast as I could.

446.92.text: The next day, no matter what happens,

456.16.text: It's when I went to a burger joint,

458.48.text:
I finished lunch,
and I went to the cashier and said,

461.00.text: "Hi, can I get a burger refill?"

464.80.text:
He was all confused,
like, "What's a burger refill?"

468.56.text:
I said, "Well, it's just like
a drink refill but with a burger."

472.24.text:
And he said, "Sorry,
we don't do burger refill, man."

476.12.text:
So this is where rejection happened
and I could have run, but I stayed.

480.20.text: I said, "Well, I love your burgers,

483.80.text: and if you guys do a burger refill,

485.92.text: I will love you guys more."

488.56.text:
And he said, "Well, OK,
I'll tell my manager about it,

491.20.text:
and maybe we'll do it,
but sorry, we can't do this today."

497.52.text:
I don't think they've
ever done burger refill.

503.16.text:
But the life and death feeling
I was feeling the first time

511.24.text:
I said, "Wow, great,
I'm already learning things.

And then Day Three:
Getting Olympic Doughnuts.

518.76.text:
This is where my life
was turned upside down.

522.12.text: I went to a Krispy Kreme.

525.00.text:
in mainly the Southeastern part
of the United States.

530.80.text:
I said, "Can you make me doughnuts
that look like Olympic symbols?

533.96.text:
Basically, you interlink
five doughnuts together ... "

536.88.text:
I mean there's no way
they could say yes, right?

539.64.text: The doughnut maker took me so seriously.

544.52.text:
started jotting down
the colors and the rings,

546.72.text: and is like, "How can I make this?"

550.68.text:
she came out with a box
that looked like Olympic rings.

557.96.text:
And that video got
over five million views on Youtube.

562.44.text: The world couldn't believe that either.

567.44.text:
You know, because of that
I was in newspapers,

573.64.text:
A lot of people
started writing emails to me

575.80.text:
and saying, "What you're

578.36.text:
But you know, fame and notoriety
did not do anything to me.

581.92.text: What I really wanted to do was learn,

585.00.text:
So I turned the rest
of my 100 days of rejection

591.72.text: I wanted to see what I could learn.

594.24.text: And then I learned a lot of things.

597.64.text: For example, I found if I just don't run,

601.84.text: I could actually turn a "no" into a "yes,"

605.56.text:
So one day I went to a stranger's house,
I had this flower in my hand,

609.68.text: knocked on the door and said,

611.12.text:
"Hey, can I plant this flower
in your backyard?"

617.64.text: But before he could leave I said,

621.36.text: And he said, "Well, I have this dog

624.44.text:
that would dig up
anything I put in the backyard.

626.80.text: I don't want to waste your flower.

628.48.text:
If you want to do this,
go across the street and talk to Connie.

634.16.text:
I went across and knocked
on Connie's door.

636.24.text: And she was so happy to see me.

639.84.text: And then half an hour later,

641.24.text:
there was this flower
in Connie's backyard.

643.32.text: I'm sure it looks better now.

646.08.text:
But had I left
after the initial rejection,

650.28.text:
well, it's because
the guy didn't trust me,

653.60.text:
because I didn't dress up well,
I didn't look good.

657.28.text:
It was because what I offered
did not fit what he wanted.

660.00.text:
And he trusted me enough
to offer me a referral,

667.80.text:
and I also learned that I can
actually say certain things

670.72.text: and maximize my chance to get a yes.

672.68.text:
So for example,
one day I went to a Starbucks,

674.92.text:
and asked the manager,
"Hey, can I be a Starbucks greeter?"

678.52.text: He was like, "What's a Starbucks greeter?"

680.92.text:
I said, "Do you know
those Walmart greeters?

683.04.text:
You know, those people who say
'hi' to you before you walk in the store,

686.48.text:
and make sure you
don't steal stuff, basically?

688.72.text:
I want to give a Walmart experience
to Starbucks customers."

693.36.text:
Well, I'm not sure
that's a good thing, actually --

697.60.text:
Actually, I'm pretty sure
it's a bad thing.

702.20.text:
yeah, this is how he looked,
his name is Eric --

704.48.text: and he was like, "I'm not sure."

706.08.text: This is how he was hearing me. "Not sure."

708.16.text: Then I ask him, "Is that weird?"

709.84.text: He's like, "Yeah, it's really weird, man."

712.80.text:
But as soon as he said that,
his whole demeanor changed.

715.68.text:
It's as if he's putting
all the doubt on the floor.

718.64.text: And he said, "Yeah, you can do this,

723.12.text:
So for the next hour
I was the Starbucks greeter.

725.52.text:
I said "hi" to every customer
that walked in,

730.08.text:
By the way, I don't know
what your career trajectory is,

737.20.text:
But then I found I could do this
because I mentioned, "Is that weird?"

742.16.text: I mentioned the doubt that he was having.

744.32.text:
And because I mentioned, "Is that weird?",
that means I wasn't weird.

747.88.text:
That means I was actually
thinking just like him,

750.44.text: seeing this as a weird thing.

754.12.text:
I learned that if I mention
some doubt people might have

760.40.text: People were more likely to say yes to me.

762.80.text:
And then I learned
I could fulfill my life dream ...

767.60.text:
You know, I came
from four generations of teachers,

770.72.text: and my grandma has always told me,

773.56.text: "Hey Jia, you can do anything you want,

775.88.text:
but it'd be great
if you became a teacher."

779.40.text:
But I wanted to be
an entrepreneur, so I didn't.

781.68.text:
But it has always been my dream
to actually teach something.

785.08.text: So I said, "What if I just ask

789.56.text: I lived in Austin at the time,

791.04.text:
so I went to University
of Texas at Austin

793.12.text:
and knocked on professors' doors
and said, "Can I teach your class?"

796.36.text:
I didn't get anywhere
the first couple of times.

798.88.text:
But because I didn't run --
I kept doing it --

801.40.text:
and on the third try
the professor was very impressed.

804.76.text:
He was like, "No one
has done this before."

806.84.text:
And I came in prepared
with powerpoints and my lesson.

810.88.text: He said, "Wow, I can use this.

812.96.text:
Why don't you come back in two months?
I'll fit you in my curriculum."

816.32.text:
And two months later
I was teaching a class.

818.44.text:
This is me -- you probably can't see,
this is a bad picture.

821.72.text:
You know, sometimes you get
rejected by lighting, you know?

827.92.text:
when I finished teaching that class,
I walked out crying,

832.48.text:
I could fulfill my life dream
just by simply asking.

835.80.text:
I used to think I have to accomplish
all these things --

838.48.text:
have to be a great entrepreneur,
or get a PhD to teach --

845.40.text:
And in that picture,
which you can't see,

847.80.text: I quoted Martin Luther King, Jr.

851.12.text:
Why? Because in my research I found
that people who really change the world,

855.68.text:
who change the way we live
and the way we think,

858.64.text:
are the people who were met
with initial and often violent rejections.

862.76.text: People like Martin Luther King, Jr.,

868.48.text:
These people did not
let rejection define them.

871.88.text:
They let their own reaction
after rejection define themselves.

879.36.text:
And we don't have to be those people
to learn about rejection,

887.20.text:
It has bothered me my whole life
because I was running away from it.

893.80.text:
I turned that into
the biggest gift in my life.

897.32.text:
I started teaching people
how to turn rejections into opportunities.

901.80.text: I use my blog, I use my talk,

903.84.text: I use the book I just published,

905.76.text:
and I'm even building technology to help
people overcome their fear of rejection.

912.20.text: When you get rejected in life,

913.96.text: when you are facing the next obstacle

922.56.text: they might become your gifts as well.
